concept.title: Quick Start Step 4:
concept.shortdesc: During this step you will use Terraform to create an cluster on .

ol.li: Decompress the archive into a convenient directory.

Navigate to the directory.
If you do not connect through a proxy, use the files in /direct_internet
If you connect through a proxy, use the files in /proxied_internet
Make a copy of the overrides.tfvars.sample file, for example myVars.tfvars.The tfvars file will contain the keys and credentials for your cluster.
Add variables to your tfvars file. For more information and examples, see Terraform Variables.

Apply the Terraform variables, for example:terraform apply -var-file=myVars.tfvarsTo improve console output on Windows, add the -no-color flag to your command. For more information, see the Terraform documentation on Command: Apply.

stentry.p: Terraform creates the necessary nodes and security groups and saves the state of your infrastructure to terraform.tfstate.At the end of the process, Terraform displays the URL of the core, formatted using the xip.io wildcard DNS, for example:api_endpoint = https://api.203.0.113.0.xip.ioYou will need this URL to use the Cloud Foundry CLI. You can also run the terraform show command to see detailed information about the core.
After is deployed on , you can view its nodes and security groups:

ul.li: To view the nodes, click Project Compute Instances .
To view the security groups, click Project Computer Access and Security .
